Yes, there are a few stories in Hindu mythology that involve attempts to steal or take control of the Sudarshana Chakra.

One such story is about the demon named Mura who possessed a boon that made him invulnerable to all weapons except the Sudarshana Chakra. Feeling invincible, Mura started tormenting the Devas, who then sought Lord Vishnu's help. Lord Vishnu fought with Mura for several years, but the demon remained invincible until finally, Lord Vishnu released his Sudarshana Chakra, which destroyed Mura instantly.

Another story involves the demon named Hayagriva who stole the sacred scriptures from Lord Brahma. Lord Vishnu, in his avatar as Hayagriva, battled Hayagriva for the scriptures. In the end, Hayagriva was killed by Lord Vishnu's Sudarshana Chakra, and the scriptures were returned to Lord Brahma.

There is also a story of a king named Ambarisha who angered the powerful sage Durvasa. Durvasa, wanting to punish Ambarisha, called forth a fire serpent to attack him. Ambarisha prayed to Lord Vishnu for help, and the Sudarshana Chakra appeared to protect him from the serpent. Durvasa became angry at the Sudarshana Chakra's interference and cursed it to wander the earth without Lord Vishnu's command. Lord Vishnu reconciled with Durvasa, and the curse was lifted.

These stories demonstrate the power and significance of the Sudarshana Chakra and how it remains exclusive to Lord Vishnu and his avatars.
